author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien
title: The Senate confirmed Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a former congresswoman with a pro-union record, as secretary of labor.
description: While in Congress, Ms. Chavez-DeRemer was a co-sponsor of the Protecting the Right to Organize Act, known as the PRO Act, a sweeping labor bill that sought to strengthen collective bargaining rights.
content: Lori Chavez-DeRemer, a Republican former congresswoman whose past support for organized labor earned her skepticism and support across party lines, was confirmed by the Senate on Monday to lead the Labor Department for the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Gallagher
title: Alas, Clothes Can’t Compete With Video Games
description: A fashion show in Paris was staged against a backdrop of 200 people playing Fortnite together. It was a distraction, at best.
content: The models whooshed by in slinky pants, sailor tops, and finger-toed sneakers, but my seatmate noticed none of it. He was too busy blasting his way up the leaderboard in Fortnite. A triangular tube-top shooting flames could’ve gone by and this man would’ve continued hammering on his computer keyboard like Liberace at the piano.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: Kennedy Links Measles Outbreak to Poor Diet and Health, Citing Fringe Theories
description: In a recent interview, the health secretary also suggested that the measles vaccine had harmed children in West Texas, center of an outbreak.
content: In a sweeping interview, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the health and human services secretary, outlined a strategy for containing the measles outbreak in West Texas that strayed far from mainstream science, relying heavily on fringe theories about prevention and treatments.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: March 10, 2025
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 10, 2025.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: New Canadian Leader’s Balancing Act: Negotiate With and Fight Trump
description: Mark Carney will most likely be in power just a few weeks before a federal election is held. To win, he will try to convince Canadians he can take on, but also negotiate with, Trump.
content: Mark Carney, Canada’s soon-to-be prime minister, weathered two era-defining implosions in his career as a central banker: the 2008 global financial crisis and Brexit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Everyone Has a Plan for Gaza. None of Them Add Up.
description: Since President Trump’s suggestion to expel the territory’s population, Middle East leaders have rushed to propose options for a postwar Gaza. Each is unacceptable to either Israel or Hamas, or both.
content: Under President Trump’s plan, the United States would govern Gaza and expel its residents. Under the Arab plan, Gaza would be run by Palestinian technocrats within a wider Palestinian state. By one Israeli proposal, Israel would cede some control to Palestinians but block Palestinian statehood. By another, Israel would occupy the entire territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: A Young Prince of Luxembourg Dies of a Rare Genetic Disease
description: Prince Frederik, 22, was a founder and the creative director of a foundation that raised awareness of POLG disorder.
content: A prince of Luxembourg has died at 22 of a genetic disease for which he spent his brief life raising awareness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: A Facebook Insider’s Exposé Alleges Bad Behavior at the Top
description: “Careless People,” a memoir by a former Facebook executive, portrays feckless company leaders cozying up to authoritarian regimes.
content: The publisher of “Careless People” kept the existence of this memoir a secret until a few days ago — with good reason, it turns out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Enduring Images of a Global Crisis
description: New York Times photographers covered Covid-19 throughout the world. These pictures, and the moments behind them, stayed with them.
content: We asked 19 photographers to revisit their most enduring images of the coronavirus pandemic, five years after the virus became a global threat. Their photographs transport us to that bewildering period in an uncanny sort of time travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Jonathan Swan
title: Trump, With More Honey Than Vinegar, Cements an Iron Grip on Republicans
description: In his second term, President Trump is cultivating warm relationships with G.O.P. lawmakers — and using the implicit threat of ruining them if they stray — to keep them in line behind his agenda.
content: Ahead of the opening day of the new Congress, Representative Chip Roy, who was refusing to commit to voting for Speaker Mike Johnson’s re-election, took an intense phone call from President-elect Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Canada’s next prime minister.
content: The Liberal Party of Canada yesterday chose Mark Carney, a technocrat with deep experience in financial markets, to replace Justin Trudeau as its leader and the country’s prime minister, and to take on President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Tuesday Briefing: U.S. Recession Fear Rattles Markets
description: Plus, how a leader’s gambit failed.
content: Stock markets around the world fell yesterday, a day after President Trump refused to rule out the possibility that his trade policies may cause a recession this year. The S&P 500 was down by nearly 3 percent, the sharpest drop in months. Several retaliatory tariffs against the U.S. also went into effect. Here’s what to know:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Are You Motivated by Being Competitive With Others?
description: When it comes to your goals, what inspires you more: the opportunity to do your best or the chance to do better than someone else?
content: Suppose you were asked for advice about how to achieve a goal, whether in academics, sports, the arts or anything else. What would you say?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Zelensky Meets With Saudi Crown Prince Before U.S.-Ukraine Talks
description: The prince wants Saudi Arabia to be a middleman in peace talks. Ukraine’s leader said they’d discussed “steps and conditions needed to end the war.”
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, working to repair his strained relationship with the United States and secure a favorable deal to end the war with Russia, met on Monday with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman in Saudi Arabia.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Agenda for the Democratic Party
description: Readers respond to a guest essay about the Democrats’ need for a Project 2029. Also: President Trump’s tariff pause; a Black Lives Matter mural.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Washington Post Columnist Resigns After Paper Spiked Criticism of Jeff Bezos
description: Ruth Marcus, a longtime columnist at The Post, said its publisher refused to run her critique of the new focus for the paper’s opinion section.
content: Ruth Marcus, a columnist and editor for The Washington Post’s opinion section, said Monday she was leaving the newspaper after Will Lewis, the paper’s publisher, killed a column she wrote that was critical of the editorial pages’ new direction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Jesus Jiménez
title: After the L.A. Wildfires, a Lingering Anxiety: What Is in the Soil?
description: Federal agencies are removing topsoil from burned areas but will not test it for contaminants. So scientists and residents are testing fire-affected properties themselves.
content: At a glance, the community garden plot appears bountiful. Its beds, flanked by lavender plants, are lush with parsley, lettuces and kale that are weeks overgrown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Trump Has Said ‘No Exceptions’ to His Tariffs. Will That Last?
description: His administration has acknowledged that exceptions undercut the power of tariffs, but it seems hard for the president to resist making deals.
content: As he prepares to introduce new tariffs on foreign metals this week, President Trump has vowed not to grant the types of exclusions and exemptions that were common during his first trade war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Will Jarvis, Ian Stewart, Jessica Metzger and Christina Goldbaum
title: Trump Won’t Rule Out a Recession, and a Crackdown on Campus Protests
description: Plus, the Oscar film that pets are watching.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: ‘All Nighter’ Review: No Sleep but Plenty of Gripes
description: A new play about a group of college students putting in one last study session evokes recent stories about young women, but without the well-rounded characters.
content: The all-nighter is a time-honored tradition of higher education (and also — let’s be honest, as I write this review in the late evening hours — of journalism). The best kind of all-nighter isn’t the solo cram session but a social event, a time of bonding through exhaustion and desperation, with the aid of caffeine and junk food.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Amazon Prime Begins Streaming ‘The Apprentice,’ Trump’s Star Vehicle
description: The company said it would release several seasons of the reality show showcasing Donald J. Trump before he turned to politics.
content: Amazon is deepening its relationship with President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: This Is the Greatest Threat to Free Speech Since the Red Scare
description: Mahmoud Khalil’s detention is a frightening sign of an authoritarian slide.
content: On Saturday, immigration agents showed up at the apartment building of Mahmoud Khalil, a leader of last year’s pro-Palestinian protests at Columbia University, and told him his student visa had been revoked and that he was being detained. Khalil is married to an American, and his lawyer, speaking to the agents by phone, informed them that he had a green card, but they said that had been revoked as well. He was taken away, and as of this writing appears to be in a detention facility in Louisiana.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devlin Barrett
title: Justice Dept. Official Says She Was Fired After Opposing Restoring Mel Gibson’s Gun Rights
description: Elizabeth G. Oyer, the former pardon attorney, said that she was not told why she was dismissed, but that as events unfolded she feared they might lead to her firing.
content: The Justice Department’s pardon attorney was dismissed a day after she refused to recommend that the actor Mel Gibson, a prominent supporter of President Trump’s, should have his gun rights restored, according to the attorney and others familiar with the situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Ukraine Must Cede Territory in Any Peace Deal, Rubio Says
description: The secretary of state, heading to talks with Ukrainian officials in Saudi Arabia, said future talks with Moscow will be needed to determine what Russia is willing to give up to end the war.
content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio said on Monday that Ukraine would have to make concessions over land that Russia had taken since 2014 as part of any agreement to end the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Fortney
title: It’s 11:30 p.m., and the Yemeni Coffee Shop Is Jumping
description: These coffeehouses are meeting demand for late-night spaces that decenter alcohol. During Ramadan, some are packed until 3 a.m.
content: On a recent Saturday night, diners in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, took their rightful places at the natural wine bars, pizza shops and taquerias across the neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: ‘Everybody’s Live With John Mulaney,’ Plus 6 Things to Watch on TV this Week
description: A live talk show comes to Netflix, Ringo Starr performs in Nashville and Amanda Seyfried plays a Philadelphia police officer.
content: Between streaming and cable, there is a seemingly endless variety of things to watch. Here is a selection of TV shows and specials that air or stream this week, March 6-10. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango and Matt Stevens
title: L.A. Prosecutor Says He Opposes Releasing the Menendez Brothers
description: Erik and Lyle Menendez still have paths to freedom. But the new district attorney is trying to roll back an effort by his predecessor to ease their punishment for killing their parents.
content: The new district attorney of Los Angeles County said he would ask a court to withdraw a resentencing petition put forward by his predecessor in the case of Lyle and Erik Menendez, two brothers who brutally murdered their parents more than 35 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edward Wong, Charlie Savage, Hamed Aleaziz and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Trump Administration Seeks to Expel a Green-Card Holder Over Student Protests
description: Immigration officers arrested a Columbia University graduate for helping lead campus protests against Israel’s treatment of Palestinians. President Trump said the case was “the first arrest of many to come.”
content: The Trump administration invoked an obscure legal statute over the weekend in an attempt to deport a recent Columbia University graduate — and lawful permanent resident of the United States — who helped lead campus protests against Israel last year, people with knowledge of the action said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Shain
title: What Should I Wear to Work Out?
description: Every fabric has an environmental cost. Here’s how to make informed choices.
content: Chances are, your favorite exercise attire is synthetic, made from petroleum-based fibers like nylon, spandex and polyester. Materials that don’t exactly scream “climate friendly.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: How ‘Operation Mincemeat,’ a Very British Hit, Was Fine-Tuned for Broadway
description: Now in previews, the musical comedy about an outrageous World War II spy mission is working to adjust to the particular sensibilities of its New York audience.
content: Last year, the hit West End musical “Operation Mincemeat” embarked on a mischievous publicity campaign. “Are we too British for Broadway?” it asked, inviting Americans on its email list and via social media to fill out an online questionnaire about whether, for instance, they had trouble understanding British accents. (“No,” 90.2 percent of the respondents said.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: For #MeToo Movement, Mayor’s Race in New York City Poses a Test
description: Three mayoral candidates have been accused of sexual misconduct. They deny wrongdoing. Will it be a deciding issue for Democratic voters?
content: Four years ago, allegations of sexual misconduct turned the New York political sphere upside down.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quote of the Day: Ambitious Democrats Have a New Game Plan: Yak It Up About Sports
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 10, 2025.
content: “As governor, you have two jobs when it comes to collegiate basketball. No. 1, to root for your in-state schools, and No. 2, to root against Duke.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai
title: Ontario Hits Michigan, Minnesota and New York With Electricity Surcharge
description: Premier Doug Ford warned that he was prepared to cut off power exports to the three states entirely as long as President Trump’s tariff threats remain.
content: Ontario, Canada’s most populous province, retaliated against President Trump’s economic threats on Monday by imposing a 25 percent surcharge on the electricity that it exports to Michigan, Minnesota and New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Butter-Basted Chicken Breasts With Rosemary and Garlic
description: Among fans of chicken breasts, some love them for their leanness, and others in spite of it. Ali Slagle’s got great news for that second group.
content: Among fans of chicken breasts, some love them for their leanness, and others in spite of it. Ali Slagle’s got great news for that second group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: Supreme Court Rejects an Effort to Block States From Suing Oil Giants
description: The justices declined to hear unusual arguments from Republican-led states that sought to end lawsuits against energy companies over their role in global warming.
content: The Supreme Court on Monday declined to hear an argument that aimed to restrict states from suing oil companies for financial damage related to climate change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear Challenge to Law Banning Conversion Therapy
description: Colorado, like more than 20 other states, bars licensed therapists from trying to change the sexual orientation or gender identity of minors in their care.
content: The Supreme Court said on Monday that it will hear a First Amendment challenge to a Colorado law banning professional counseling services engaged in conversion therapy intended to change a minor’s gender identity or sexual orientation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora
title: Russian Forces Depleted and Stalling on Eastern Front, Ukraine Says
description: The front line inside Ukraine has become more static, Ukrainian soldiers say, even as Russia regains ground in its own Kursk region.
content: Ukrainian forces have stalled the Russian offensive in the eastern Donetsk region in recent months and have started to win back small patches of land, according to Ukrainian soldiers and military analysts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christian Ulloriaq Jeppesen, Maya Tekeli and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: Trump Looms Over Greenland’s Election, but Voters Have Other Concerns
description: President Trump keeps saying he wants to “get” Greenland. On Tuesday, Greenland votes for a new parliament that could shape its future relations with the United States.
content: The air inside the community hall in Greenland’s capital was thick with warmth, a welcome contrast to the icy streets outside. As voters brushed snow from their coats, candidates from most of Greenland’s major parties sat down in the front of the room, ready for questions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Origin Story
description: Little-known stories of how all sorts of institutions began.
content: On This Week’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Ruberg
title: Fire Damages 4 Tesla Cybertrucks in Seattle
description: Federal and local law enforcement authorities are investigating what caused the Sunday night fire, which came after a series of attacks against Tesla in rebuke of its chief executive, Elon Musk.
content: The police in Seattle are investigating a fire that damaged four Tesla Cybertrucks parked in an electric vehicle storage lot late Sunday night, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi, busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. Enter the comments section to see hints, conversation, helpful tips and creative content from other solvers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alix Strauss and Amir Hamja
title: Step Off the No. 1 Train and Into La Noxe
description: A hidden bar has taken hold in the netherworld of a subway station in Chelsea.
content: Harried New Yorkers might easily miss the brown door on the platform separating the street from the subway at the station on 28th Street at Seventh Avenue — home to the No. 1 train. Half a flight of stairs up, and you have the street. Half a flight down, the turnstiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Defendant in U.S.S. Cole Bombing Case Signs Plea Offer
description: The Saudi prisoner agreed to the settlement to avoid a death-penalty trial, his lawyer said, but it has yet to reach the defense secretary.
content: A Saudi prisoner accused of plotting Al Qaeda’s bombing of the U.S.S. Cole warship in 2000 has signed an offer to plead guilty to avoid a death-penalty trial, his lawyer announced Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Jean Smart Will Star in a One-Woman Broadway Show
description: The new play, “Call Me Izzy,” will begin previews in May and open in June at Studio 54.
content: Jean Smart, a veteran stage and screen actress whose oft-praised comedic chops reached new audiences via the Max series “Hacks,” plans to return to Broadway this spring and summer in a one-woman show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum, Nina Agrawal and Alice Callahan
title: A Clearer Picture of Covid’s Lasting Effects on the Body
description: Five years on, scientists are starting to understand how the virus can lead to long-term, sometimes invisible changes.
content: Five years — and hundreds of millions of cases — after the World Health Organization declared the Covid-19 pandemic, scientists are getting a clearer picture of how the virus can affect the body long after an infection seems to pass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: What We Know About the Month-Old Migrant Mission at Guantánamo Bay
description: President Trump said the base would house as many as 30,000 migrants awaiting deportation. But construction of a tent city was halted weeks ago.
content: In little over a month, the Trump administration has moved fewer than 300 men from an immigration holding site in Texas to the U.S. military base at Guantánamo Bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Gelinas
title: A Simple Way to Check Police Corruption? Parking Tickets.
description: Cracking down on officers’ abuse of placards would signal an end to the culture of impunity that has suffused the department.
content: On a February morning, as light snow turned to light rain, traffic backed up behind a truck on a Brooklyn side street. The driver had stepped out to measure whether he could get past one of a long line of parked S.U.V.s and sedans, jutting off the sidewalk and into the street, outside the 67th Precinct station house in East Flatbush.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mukherjee
title: Covid’s Deadliest Effect Took Five Years to Appear
description: What once belonged to all of us now belongs to corporations.
content: February 2025. A blustery morning. I alight, a little breathless, from the subway at 168th Street and walk the oddly deserted blocks toward the hospital where I work. I hear a distant cough. A windblown plastic bag tumbles along the sidewalk and lodges itself in the skeletal branches of a tree. The familiar, insistent whine of an ambulance rises in the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal and Atul Loke
title: His Bollywood Spoofs Brought Joy to a Mill Town. Then Bollywood Came Calling.
description: An Indian biopic tells the story of Nasir Shaikh, whose no-budget, all-heart productions gave his home city of Malegaon a film industry of its own.
content: Nasir Shaikh, the sleeves of his suede jacket rolled up, used his phone camera as a pocket mirror to touch up his hair. Then he stepped onto the red carpet (it was blue, actually) and stood beneath banners dedicated to filmmaking giants like Chaplin, Scorsese and Spielberg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Goldbaum and Euan Ward
title: Syrian Government Signs Breakthrough Deal With Kurdish-Led Forces
description: The agreement marked a major victory for Damascus in its quest to unify the country, as violent unrest continues to grip Syria’s coastal region.
content: The Kurdish-led militia that controls northeastern Syria agreed on Monday to merge with the country’s new government, marking a major breakthrough for Damascus in its efforts to unify a country still wrestling with violent turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Jacey Fortin
title: Pressed by Republicans, D.C. Begins Removing Black Lives Matter Mural
description: The mural, which covers two city blocks, was painted in 2020. A jackhammer began chipping away at the bright yellow letters on Monday morning.
content: Local government crews in Washington began on Monday morning to remove the Black Lives Matter mural that was painted near the White House nearly five years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Edmund Lee
title: Would Trump Risk a Recession?
description: The president still believes that his protectionist trade policies will be “great for us” in the long run, but won’t rule out short-term economic pain.
content: Even President Trump has acknowledged that his pugnacious economic agenda is looking increasingly risky. Asked on Fox News this weekend if he expected a recession this year, he allowed only, “I hate to predict things like that.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: She Goes to Trader Joe’s for the Art
description: Julie Averbach has written a book celebrating the displays, the murals and the installations at the grocery store chain.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at the art shoppers can find when they go to a Trader Joe’s in Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack
title: Why Immigrants Fear Trump Even if They Voted for Him
description: Talking to people around Chicago, I heard the word “resentment” over and over.
content: The two men burst from the ice-crusted street into the warm cavern of a taqueria, shaking snow off puffed jackets and adjusting the brims of ball caps. They’d ventured into the Chicago night only because we’d arranged to meet. Otherwise, like many immigrants across the country, they’ve been sticking close to home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Rysman
title: 4 Trains, 5 Cities: A Whirlwind European Odyssey
description: Milan, Zurich, Berlin, Copenhagen and Stockholm: Our writer devised her own urban grand tour to some of the continent’s most dazzling cities.
content: A century after the original golden era of railroads, trains are once again the talk of travel. In Europe, especially, train travel is surging as an environmental alternative to short-haul flights, with more night trains, high-speed routes and transnational collaboration between rail companies. Political ties between European countries may be jittery, but the cities are more linked than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Gross
title: Jam Like a King: Charles Releases a Playlist
description: King Charles III showcased 17 artists, mostly from Commonwealth countries, in a personal playlist. Beyoncé, Bob Marley and Diana Ross made the cut.
content: King Charles III, a classical music fan who has studied the cello, piano and trumpet, released an eclectic playlist on Monday featuring 17 artists, including Beyoncé, Bob Marley and Grace Jones.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle and Ana Swanson
title: Trump’s Call to Scrap ‘Horrible’ Chip Program Spreads Panic
description: The president’s attack on the key tenet of the Biden administration’s industrial policy has set off concerns that he may claw back its funding.
content: As President Trump addressed Congress last week, he veered off script to attack a sensitive topic, the CHIPS Act, a bipartisan law aimed at making the United States less reliant on Asia for semiconductors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Mutated DNA Restored to Normal in Gene Therapy Advance
description: The small study in patients with a rare disorder that causes liver and lung damage showed the potential for precisely targeted infusions.
content: Researchers have corrected a disease-causing gene mutation with a single infusion carrying a treatment that precisely targeted the errant gene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Aftershocks of Supreme Court’s Immunity Ruling Echo in New Trump Cases
description: The real legacy of the case, scholars say, is not its protection of former presidents from prosecution but its expansive understanding of presidential power.
content: The first case cited as precedent in the first Supreme Court brief filed by lawyers for President Trump since he took office this year was Trump v. United States, the July decision that gave him substantial immunity from prosecution. That citation was the first of nine. A second brief, filed days later, cited the decision eight more times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Duehren
title: Stalled Audits and a Skeleton Staff: Inside Trump’s War on the I.R.S.
description: President Trump is planning to gut the work force while trying to turn the I.R.S. into a more political agency.
content: Beth Crowell was proud to work for the Internal Revenue Service.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ryan Christopher Jones
title: The Otherworldly California Waterway That Keeps Exploding Into Politics
description: If we are to take seriously the threats of drought, climate change and water security, we should not reduce this place to a warring of two — or even many — sides.
content: The sprawling estuary about 70 miles inland from San Francisco feels distinctly out of place — more like the swampy Florida Everglades than arid California. But from that confluence of two great rivers, the Sacramento and the San Joaquin, 1,100 miles of webbed waterways and levees send upward of six million acre-feet of freshwater a year to thirstier parts of the state, from farms in the San Joaquin Valley to the Southern California megalopolis. Known as the California Delta, the estuary is among the state’s most important sources of water — and most consistent flash points over environmental protection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Senator Mark Kelly Urges Continued U.S. Support After Visiting Ukraine. Musk Calls Him a ‘Traitor.’
description: Senator Mark Kelly, an Arizona Democrat and former astronaut, visited Ukraine over the weekend and said the United States could not give up on the people there as they fight Russia. Musk responded on X.
content: Elon Musk, the tech billionaire and one of President Trump’s top advisers, on Monday accused Senator Mark Kelly, Democrat of Arizona, of being a “traitor” after he visited Ukraine and said the United States should keep supporting its war against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Trial Set for Men Accused of Targeting Iranian Dissident in New York
description: Prosecutors say the men helped direct a murder-for-hire scheme aimed at Masih Alinejad. The trial is expected to show Iran’s efforts to punish those who criticize it, no matter where they are.
content: First, the Iranian government was accused of trying to lure a journalist and dissident from New York City to Turkey to abduct and imprison her. Then, according to U.S. officials, intelligence agents schemed unsuccessfully to kidnap the woman, Masih Alinejad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: When It Comes to the Economy, Does Trump Have Musk’s Pain Tolerance?
description: Wall Street’s slide puts pressure on Musk and Trump, for different reasons.
content: The stock market today was full of bad news for both President Trump and Elon Musk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Brian Tyree Henry Isn’t Hiding
description: Since breaking out in “Atlanta,” the actor has become a dependable Hollywood side man. In “Dope Thief,” a new crime drama, he will finally take the lead.
content: The actor Brian Tyree Henry made his professional debut in 2007, as Tybalt, in a shimmering “Romeo and Juliet” for Shakespeare in the Park. More stage roles followed, then a nimble leap to television, in “Atlanta,” and a turn to film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,361
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, March 11, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caroline Hopkins Legaspi
title: How Healthy Are Eggs?
description: Their nutritional reputation has had ups and downs. Here’s where it stands today.
content: To many nutrition experts, eggs are golden — one of the most accessible and affordable protein sources available.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Vjosa Isai
title: Canada Will Have a New Prime Minister. Here’s What to Know.
description: Mark Carney, a former central banker, now heads the Liberal Party and will soon lead Canada, tasked with responding to President Trump’s threats.
content: Mark Carney, a former central banker, swept to the leadership of Canada’s Liberal Party on Sunday and will become prime minister at a critical moment for the country, which is facing threats to its economy and sovereignty from President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘The White Lotus’ Season 3, Episode 4 Recap: Party Time
description: The gal pals finally moved out of their hermetic bubble this week in search of a little fun. The results were questionable.
content: There is something about the experience of being on a luxury vacation that can get into the vacationers’ heads. Mike White understands this. Through three seasons of “The White Lotus,” he has focused on the nagging dissatisfaction of the privileged — especially when they are supposed to be at leisure. Are they really enjoying themselves? Are they getting the escape from the everyday they needed? Most important: Are they getting their money’s worth?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Barker
title: Trump’s Attacks Give Zelensky a Bit of a Reprieve at Home
description: The Ukrainian leader’s approval rating is rising, and critics have backed off after he was humiliated and criticized by President Trump, who has also demanded new elections in Ukraine.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine was losing popularity at home for months, seen by many as a thin-skinned leader who had concentrated power around him. Political opponents saw an opening to win a future election against him. His former top general in the war against Russia had a higher approval rating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Ley
title: Columbia Activist in Detention Was Public Face of Protest Against Israel
description: Mahmoud Khalil, a permanent resident of the United States, was arrested in his Manhattan apartment and sent to Louisiana. His detention sets up a fight over free speech.
content: As protests over the Gaza conflict ignited rancor and division at Columbia University last year, one student stood out for his role as a negotiator representing activists in talks with the school officials who were desperate to achieve peace on campus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully
title: For a Family That Lost 5 Loved Ones, ‘Covid Will Never Be Over’
description: Elizabeth Fusco’s relatives had their usual family dinner in New Jersey in early 2020. Soon, her mother, three siblings and aunt were all dead.
content: The quality that made the tightly knit Fusco family great was the very thing that exacted the harshest price.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis
title: Japan’s trade minister heads to Washington for tariff talks.
description: The minister, Yoji Muto, is expected to negotiate with U.S. officials ahead of global tariffs that could damage Japanese businesses, including automotive giants.
content: Japanese officials are visiting Washington this week to negotiate with the Trump administration ahead of sweeping U.S. tariffs that are set to affect exports, including metals and cars, from Japan and a number of other countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: Who Likes Tariffs? Some U.S. Industries Are Eager for Them.
description: Concern about the cost of materials has tempered business enthusiasm about taxing imports. But steel and aluminum makers say they welcome the help.
content: The United States buys more steel from Canada than from any other country, and those imports will become much more expensive under tariffs President Trump intends to impose this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Our 16th Annual Summer Reading Contest
description: Students are invited to tell us what they’re reading in The Times and why, this year in writing OR via a 90-second video. Contest dates: June 6 to Aug. 15, 2025.
content: Our Summer Reading Contest is our longest-running challenge — and our simplest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Severson, Dana Goldstein, Eric Krupke, Sydney Harper, Nina Feldman, Devon Taylor, Pat McCusker, Diane Wong, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: Trump Takes Aim at the Department of Education
description: The president promised to abolish the department. But he also needs it to impose his own vision on American schools.
content: In the coming days, President Trump is expected to sign an executive order that would follow through on one of his major campaign promises: to abolish the U.S. Department of Education. The catch is that he still needs the department to impose his vision on American schools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Euan Ward
title: Skirmish in Syrian Capital Raises Fears of Expanding Violence
description: The overnight clash in Damascus appeared to have been contained, but it has heightened concerns that the violence sweeping the country’s coastal region could spread.
content: Gunmen attacked a position held by Syrian security forces in Damascus overnight, a war monitor said on Monday, raising fears that the deadly violence sweeping Syria’s coastal region could spread to other parts of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: On ‘Mayhem,’ Lady Gaga Wants You to Party Like It’s 2009
description: She dances on the line between clever self-referentiality and less inspired rehashing on her new LP, committing to the over-the-top excess that first made her a star.
content: Even throughout Lady Gaga’s requisite ups and downs as a singer, songwriter and actress (the less said about last year’s “Joker: Folie à Deux,” the better), the 38-year-old New Yorker born Stefani Germanotta has remained imperially famous for so long, it can be difficult to recall the subversive thrill of her initial rise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Lohr and Cody O'Loughlin
title: The Quest for A.I. ‘Scientific Superintelligence’
description: An ambitious start-up embodies new optimism that artificial intelligence can turbocharge scientific discovery.
content: Across the spectrum of uses for artificial intelligence, one stands out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Delta Says Economic Worries Are Hurting Travel Demand
description: The airline lowered its financial forecast for the first quarter as economic anxiety hurts demand for tickets.
content: Delta Air Lines on Monday cut its financial forecast for the first three months of the year, saying that growing economic concerns among businesses and consumers had lowered demand for domestic travel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Couple Sought After Death of Boy, 3, Abandoned at Brooklyn Hospital
description: The child’s death is one of several in recent months. The medical examiner is seeking a cause as investigators look for the man and woman who left him.
content: The police on Monday were searching for a man and a woman connected to the death of a 3-year-old boy abandoned at a hospital in Brooklyn, according to an internal police report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Melancholy Yiddish Classic That Also Happens to Be Hilarious
description: “Sons and Daughters,” Chaim Grade’s serialized novel about Jewish life in 1930s Europe, has been published in English for the first time.
content: There’s a new old writer headed for the front tables of bookstores. The Lithuania-born Chaim Grade, who died in 1982, was one of the heavies of Yiddish literature in the 20th century. While never as well-known as Isaac Bashevis Singer or Sholem Aleichem, who also wrote in Yiddish, Grade (pronounced GRAH-duh) found an audience. His novel “Rabbis and Wives” was a finalist for the Pulitzer Prize in fiction in 1983, the year it was claimed by “The Color Purple.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raja Abdulrahim and Kiana Hayeri
title: As People Are Abducted on Unpatrolled Streets, Syrians Demand Better Protection
description: When the new government took over, it dismissed the Assad regime police and other forces, leaving a security vacuum. Now, many residents fear going out after dark.
content: The first ransom demand came in a text message on Sami al-Izoo’s phone 10 days after he witnessed his brother being kidnapped, forced into a truck with dark tinted windows by six masked men.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Trump’s Tactics Lead Americans to Question Role on World Stage
description: Among supporters and detractors alike, his transactional approach to foreign policy has upended old notions about the United States as a global leader.
content: Abraham Lincoln suggested the United States was “the last, best hope of Earth.” Ronald Reagan celebrated it as a “shining city on a hill.” George W. Bush argued that the nation was “the brightest beacon for freedom and opportunity in the world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Big Drama Cannot Distract From Irrelevant Clothes
description: It’s the wrong moment for the fashion theatrics of Valentino, McQueen and Dior. But Balenciaga got it right.
content: The Valentino show took place in a bathroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Think You Understand Your Dog? Think Again.
description: People interpret a dog’s emotions based on its situation and have “a big blind spot” for the actual animal, a new study found.
content: Dogs can’t talk, but their body language speaks volumes. Many dogs will bow when they want to play, for instance, or lick their lips and avert their gaze when nervous or afraid.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cutting Medicaid?
description: How Republicans could change the program.
content: Republican leaders in Congress have directed the committee that oversees Medicaid to cut $880 billion from the next budget. They say these cuts aren’t necessarily aimed at Medicaid, the insurance program for 72 million poor and disabled Americans. The cuts could come from Medicare, for instance. But Trump has vowed not to touch that very popular program. And a sum this large can’t come from anywhere else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Why Are So Many Women Wearing Neckties?
description: While men’s wear has shifted away from the classic necktie, more and more women are sporting the accessory. Our critic explains the infatuation and offers tips for suiting up.
content: There is a certain irony that just as men liberated themselves from the tie, using casual Fridays and pandemic-era working from home to sound its death knell pretty much once and for all, women have, as you correctly point out, embraced the accessory. Much as they continue to embrace the pantsuit while men move further away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Wildman and Derek Arthur
title: I’m a Transgender Colonel. Trump Wants Me Out.
description: “Until I am dragged away, I’m going to do my job to the utmost of my ability.”
content: Time is running out for transgender service members in the U.S. military. The Trump administration has put in motion plans to identify and remove transgender troops, with Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth saying they are unfit to serve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA Eliminates Chief Scientist and Other Jobs at Its Headquarters
description: About 19 positions will be cut, including those in offices focused on technology policy and diversity, equity and inclusion.
content: NASA is eliminating its chief scientist and other roles as part of efforts by the Trump administration to pare back staff at the agency’s Washington headquarters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: obstinacy
description: This word has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word obstinacy has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 22 in “Headstrong Francis Put the Church Above His Health, Vatican Observers Say” by Elisabetta Povoledo. The article quotes Austen Ivereigh, a commentator and papal biographer who has insight about Pope Francis’ work ethic:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Iran Signals Openness to Limited Nuclear Talks With U.S.
description: Iran’s U.N. mission said it would be willing to discuss its nuclear program if talks were restricted to military concerns, after its supreme leader appeared to reject President Trump’s offer to start discussions.
content: Iran has signaled that it is open to talks about its nuclear program with the United States if they are restricted to military concerns, a day after the country’s supreme leader had appeared to reject an overture from President Trump to hold discussions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Lasdun
title: The Cops Thrashed Him. Madonna, Spike Lee and Toni Morrison Took Notice.
description: Elon Green’s telling of the life and death of the artist Michael Stewart is filled with heartbreaking echoes of the present.
content: In the early hours of Sept. 15, 1983, a 25-year-old Black man named Michael Stewart was arrested for allegedly tagging a subway wall with a marker. According to the arresting officer, Stewart attempted to escape up the stairs, where the officer caught him, pinning him to the ground with a nightstick. Outside the precinct headquarters on Union Square, he allegedly tried to run off again, only to be piled on by multiple officers. College students in a building overlooking the square saw the officers kicking and beating the handcuffed Stewart (who weighed only 143 pounds) as he lay facedown on the sidewalk, screaming for help. One witness saw an officer slide a club under Stewart’s neck and yank it upward. After Stewart stopped moving he was thrown, hogtied, into a paddy wagon, and driven to Bellevue Hospital. There, after 13 days in a coma, he died. No one was ever held accountable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: ‘Anchors, Under Your Desks!’: Tornado Hits Orlando TV Station
description: Crews at the Fox 35 station were on the air sharing updates about tornado warnings for Seminole and Volusia counties when one struck their news studio on Monday morning.
content: As powerful storms swept across Central Florida on Monday morning, an Orlando television station’s weather camera captured a tornado hitting the station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: For Patients Needing Transplants, Hope Arrives on Tiny Hooves
description: Some scientists are confident that organs from genetically modified pigs will one day be routinely transplanted into humans. But substantial ethical questions remain.
content: On a 300-acre farm in an undisclosed location in rural Wisconsin, surrounded by fields dotted with big red barns and bordered by wild blue chicory and goldenrod, live some of the most pampered pigs in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: For Musk and Rubio, Public Niceties After a Private Clash
description: Days after Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Elon Musk sparred at the White House, Mr. Rubio announced cuts to foreign aid that Mr. Musk had ordered.
content: Secretary of State Marco Rubio and Elon Musk, the tech billionaire deputized by President Trump to slash federal spending, sought to smooth over their ugly confrontation in the White House last week with an awkward social media embrace on Monday, as Mr. Rubio formalized deep cuts to foreign aid that Mr. Musk had demanded.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Kenneth Chang
title: Eric Schmidt Joins Relativity Space, a Rocket Start-Up, as C.E.O.
description: The former Google chief executive is taking a controlling interest in Relativity Space, which aims to build low-cost, reusable rockets to compete against Elon Musk’s SpaceX and to reach Mars.
content: For a decade, Eric Schmidt ran Google as chief executive and as the “adult” in the room, mentoring the internet company’s young founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin. In 2011, Mr. Schmidt handed control of Google back to Mr. Page. He has not taken another C.E.O. job since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.5 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style house in San Rafael, an 1899 cottage in St. Helena and a 1978 condo in Santa Monica.
content: This three-bedroom, one-bathroom house is a block from the Marin Tennis Club and a five-minute walk from Dominican University of California. The Marin Museum of Contemporary Art and the Marin History Museum are less than two miles away, as is the center of San Rafael, home to restaurants, grocery stores and a Sonoma-Marin Area Rail Transit station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Fashion? Rockets? Yachts? A Trump Ally Has Ideas for the Kennedy Center
description: Paolo Zampolli, a Trump appointee on the center’s board, wants the institution to host Valentino fashion shows, send art into space and open a marina and a Cipriani restaurant.
content: The businessman Paolo Zampolli has counted Donald J. Trump as a friend for decades. In the 1990s, when Mr. Zampolli ran a modeling agency, he played matchmaker for Mr. Trump, introducing him at a party to his future wife, Melania.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Lincoln Center Gets $50 Million Gift to Promote Contemporary Dance
description: The donation from two philanthropists will support performances, commissions and young artists, at a time of uncertainty for the dance industry.
content: Dance has long been a precarious industry in New York. It can be difficult for dance troupes to find rehearsal and performance space in one of the world’s most expensive markets, and dancers often struggle to make a living.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Firm Targeted by Trump Over Clinton Campaign Work Hires Top Litigators
description: President Trump stripped Perkins Coie of access to federal buildings and personnel, citing its work for Hillary Clinton’s 2016 campaign. The firm hired Williams & Connolly, which is skilled in fighting the government, to represent it.
content: Perkins Coie, the law firm that President Trump targeted for punishment with an executive order last week for its role representing Hillary Clinton’s 2016 campaign, has hired an elite Washington firm, Williams & Connolly, to fight the order, according to four people briefed on the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: Michelle Obama’s Next Act: Video Podcaster
description: Through her production company, Higher Ground, Mrs. Obama, along with her brother, Craig Robinson, will interview celebrities and offer advice on various topics.
content: Ask any prominent podcast host for a list of dream interview guests, and it is quite likely that Michelle Obama’s name would be on it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber and Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Tariffs on U.S. Agricultural Products Take Effect
description: The action came in response to the higher levies on Chinese imports that President Trump announced last week.
content: Follow live updates on the Trump administration and global markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Karniol-Tambour
title: This Is Who Loses in a Trade War
description: Europe, not Canada, Mexico or China, is most vulnerable to the fallout from Donald Trump’s mercantilist policies.
content: For decades, the rest of the world, especially China and countries in Europe, have produced much more than they have consumed, selling goods to America in exchange for an ever-growing pile of U.S. dollars. This could happen because the United States consumes much more than it produces, gobbling up the difference in the form of persistent trade deficits, and financing those deficits with debt, which Chinese and European investors are happy to buy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Trump Gave Us a Piece of His Mind
description: The official and unofficial languages of the White House, decoded.
content: Bret Stephens: Hola, Gail. ¿Qué opinas sobre la insistencia de Donald Trump en que el inglés sea nuestro idioma oficial?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Ewing
title: Tesla Stock Tumbles as Elon Musk’s Political Role Grows More Divisive
description: The automaker’s shares soared after Election Day as Elon Musk took a high-profile role as a Trump adviser. Now those gains have evaporated.
content: Follow live updates on the Trump administration and global markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: Long Island Wildfires Began With Backyard S’mores, Police Say
description: The wildfires began accidentally when someone in Suffolk County tried to light a fire to make s’mores, officials said. They were fully contained by Monday.
content: The wildfires that broke out on Long Island Saturday afternoon and spread over hundreds of acres appeared to be accidental, caused by a failed attempt to make s’mores in a backyard, local officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua David Stein and Jake Michaels
title: Balloon Art You Won’t Find at a Children’s Birthday Party
description: DJ Morrow’s creations, inspired by his own emotional life, can disturb as much as they delight.
content: “It’s funny how little memory I have of balloons growing up,” said DJ Morrow, one of the greatest avant-garde balloon artists in the United States. “It’s almost like because it was around me constantly I didn’t even notice them.” They were, that is, like air.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer
title: U.S. Energy Secretary Pledges to Reverse Focus on Climate Change
description: To applause from oil and gas executives, Chris Wright said natural gas was preferable to renewable energy and climate change was a “side effect of building the modern world.”
content: Before a packed crowd of oil and gas executives on Monday, Chris Wright, the new U.S. energy secretary, delivered a scathing critique of the Biden administration’s energy policies and efforts to fight climate change and promised a “180 degree pivot.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephanie Saul
title: Harvard Announces a Hiring Freeze as Funding Is Threatened
description: The hiring pause at one of the nation’s wealthiest schools comes after other schools have also announced efforts to save money.
content: Harvard University, one of the nation’s wealthiest schools, on Monday joined the list of universities across the country imposing hiring freezes, citing the uncertainty created by President Trump’s threats to slash funding for higher education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger and Christine Hauser
title: Bad Day for X and Tesla Prompts Concern About Musk’s Distractions
description: The billionaire’s social media site X suffered outages, and Tesla’s stock tanked on Monday.
content: Elon Musk is facing questions about how much attention he is paying to his businesses as he advises President Trump on the direction of the federal government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
title: Rubio Seeks Cease-Fire in Ukraine After Reaching His Own With Musk
description: After blowing up at Elon Musk, Secretary of State Marco Rubio aims to bolster his position. He is seeing Saudi and Ukrainian officials in Saudi Arabia and allied diplomats in Canada.
content: Before he embarked on a round of high-stakes negotiations in Saudi Arabia and Canada this week, Secretary of State Marco Rubio engaged in some personal diplomacy aimed at shoring up his standing within the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrina Miller
title: SpaceX Again Scrubs Launch of NASA’s SPHEREx and PUNCH Missions
description: The postponement, driven primarily by thick clouds, was the second scrub of the flight since an issue with the rocket on Saturday night.
content: Two NASA missions, set for a late-night launch aboard a single rocket on Monday night, have been delayed again. Both aim to unravel mysteries about the universe — one by peering far from Earth, the other by looking closer to home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye, Eshe Nelson and Joe Rennison
title: Stocks Plunge as Recession Talk Gets Louder
description: The S&P skidded 2.7 percent, amid investor fears that tit-for-tat tariffs could raise prices, slow the economy and sow uncertainty among businesses.
content: Wall Street suffered its steepest decline of the year on Monday, a drop fueled by angst about the economy a day after President Trump refused to rule out the possibility that his policies could trigger a recession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Dunn
title: Stuck on Where to Go This Summer? We’re Here to Help!
description: Send us your vacation criteria and we’ll respond with suggestions.
content: Is there anyone who truly enjoys planning a summer vacation? It’s especially daunting if you want to go somewhere new. How do you know if a place is really as great as it seems? Will it please everyone in your traveling party? Why on earth are room rates so preposterously high? The search alone is enough to make you give up entirely and hibernate until fall. But I’m here to help. I edit travel stories for T Magazine (and before that for The Wall Street Journal and Condé Nast Traveler). I’ve traveled extensively myself, from Madagascar to Myanmar, but just as important, I know journalists and travel advisers based around the world who I constantly ask for intel and recommendations. I want to hear what type of summer vacation you’re envisioning and I’ll confer with my sources and offer our best advice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Striking Stage Crews Reach Agreement With Atlantic Theater
description: The deal will be scrutinized by New York’s other Off Broadway theaters, which the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees has been working to unionize.
content: Ending a two-month strike, the prestigious Atlantic Theater Company and the labor union representing its crew members said Monday that they had reached a tentative agreement that they anticipated would allow the theater to resume performances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Connections Companion No. 639
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Tuesday, March 11, 2025.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A Bad Day on Wall Street
description: Also, Rubio said Ukraine must cede territory in exchange for peace. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: The American stock market tumbled today to its lowest point in several months. The S&P 500 dropped 2.7 percent, its worst single-day decline of the year. And the tech-heavy Nasdaq slipped 4 percent, fueled in part by sharp drops in the stock prices of some of the U.S.’s most valuable companies — like Tesla, which fell by more than 15 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Keeping Up With Highbrow Art While Raising a Child
description: It’s not easy, but here’s how Mark Krotov, the publisher of the literary magazine n+1, attempts it, often with his 6-year-old daughter along for the ride.
content: Being the 6-year-old daughter of Mark Krotov, the publisher and one of the editors of the literary magazine n+1, is an all-access pass to New York City’s foreign films and contemporary art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: Accused Sex Traffickers Receive Warm Welcome From a Trump Ally
description: Dana White of the U.F.C. greeted Andrew Tate and his brother at an event, highlighting a divide among conservatives.
content: Dana White, the chief executive of the Ultimate Fighting Championship, is a fight promoter. That means the old saw “all publicity is good publicity” usually applies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Campbell Robertson
title: G.O.P. Spending Bill Would Force $1 Billion Cut to D.C. Budget
description: Republicans omitted a standard provision approving the District’s budget in a stopgap funding measure needed to avert a shutdown before the end of the week. The result would be a 16 percent cut.
content: The stopgap spending bill that Republicans are pushing to avert a shutdown at the end of the week would effectively slash the District of Columbia’s budget by roughly $1 billion over the next six months, a change that local leaders warn would force dramatic cuts to essential services.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Jessie Mahaffey, Survivor of Pearl Harbor Attack, Dies at 102
description: He was cleaning the deck of the U.S.S. Oklahoma when it capsized under Japanese torpedo fire. Less than a year later, he survived the sinking of another Navy ship in the Pacific.
content: Jessie Mahaffey, who was scrubbing the deck of the U.S.S. Oklahoma when it was hit by Japanese torpedoes at Pearl Harbor on Dec. 7, 1941, and who was among the last living service members who survived the surprise attack, died on March 1 in Alexandria, La. He was 102.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paula Span
title: Why Older People May Not Need to Watch Blood Sugar So Closely
description: Intensive management of diabetes pays fewer dividends as patients age and raises the chances of hypoglycemia. But many people have not gotten the message.
content: By now, Ora Larson recognizes what’s happening. “It feels like you’re shaking inside,” she said. “I’m speeded up. I’m anxious.” If someone asks whether she would like a salad for lunch, she doesn’t know how to respond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Pager
title: Trump Promised Americans Booming Wealth. Now He’s Changing His Tune.
description: President Trump’s sweeping promises are running headlong into the reality of governing.
content: Follow live updates on the Trump administration and global markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Simon Fisher-Becker, Actor in ‘Harry Potter’ and ‘Doctor Who,’ Dies at 63
description: A versatile character actor whose career spanned film, theater and television, Mr. Fisher-Becker was known for small, memorable roles.
content: Simon Fisher-Becker, a British character actor best known for his small but memorable roles in the “Harry Potter” and the “Doctor Who” franchises, died on Sunday. He was 63.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: One Person Missing After Oil Tanker and Container Ship Collide in the North Sea
description: A container ship hit a stationary U.S.-flagged oil tanker on Monday, forcing the crews to abandon ship. A search for a missing crew member ended Monday night.
content: One crew member from a container ship was missing after the vessel collided with a U.S.-flagged oil tanker off the northeastern coast of England on Monday, causing multiple explosions and forcing the crews of both ships to abandon their vessels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz and Emma Bubola
title: Pope No Longer in Immediate Danger From Illnesses, Vatican Says
description: Though his condition had improved, he will remain in the hospital for further treatment, the Vatican said in a statement.
content: Pope Francis has improved enough to no longer be considered in imminent danger from pneumonia and other infections, the Vatican said on Monday, but added that he would require more days of treatment in the Rome hospital where he has been for nearly a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Bookish Beefs: Do You Know the Great Author Feuds of Modern Literature?
description: Try this short quiz on writers who had very public spats with each other.
content: Try this short quiz on writers who had very public spats with each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun and Pablo Robles
title: How South Korea’s President Planned a Military Takeover, Then Blew It
description: Yoon Suk Yeol came close to disabling Parliament with a few hundred troops. But he misjudged the power of his people and the willingness of his army to use force. South Koreans worry it could happen again.
content: Yoon Suk Yeol came close to disabling Parliament with a few hundred troops. But he misjudged the power of his people and the willingness of his army to use force. South Koreans worry it could happen again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aatish Bhatia and Irineo Cabreros
title: 30 Charts That Show How Covid Changed Everything in March 2020
description: It can be easy to forget, or look away from, the pain and disruption of the pandemic. The numbers will be there to remind us.
content: It can be easy to forget, or look away from, the pain and disruption of the pandemic. The numbers will be there to remind us.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Paik
title: Mark Carney Set to Lead Canada and Take On Trump
description: As President Trump threatens to make Canada the 51st state, the Liberal Party chose the former central banker to succeed Justin Trudeau as prime minister.
content: As President Trump threatens to make Canada the 51st state, the Liberal Party chose the former central banker to succeed Justin Trudeau as prime minister.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Axel Boada
title: Ship Collides With Tanker Carrying Jet Fuel Cargo off England’s Coast
description: Multiple explosions were reported and jet fuel leaked after a container ship collided with an oil tanker.
content: Multiple explosions were reported and jet fuel leaked after a container ship collided with an oil tanker.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin, Christina Shaman, Christina Thornell and Laura Salaberry
title: Are Genetically Modified Pigs The Future of Organ Transplantation?
description: How have the first patients fared after receiving organ transplants from genetically modified pigs? Roni Caryn Rabin, a health reporter on the Science desk of The New York Times, looks at the results so far.
content: How have the first patients fared after receiving organ transplants from genetically modified pigs? Roni Caryn Rabin, a health reporter on the Science desk of The New York Times, looks at the results so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brent McDonald and Meg Felling
title: D.C. Mayor Removes Black Lives Matter Mural to Save City Funding
description: Crews began removing the Black Lives Matter mural in Washington on Monday after a Republican lawmaker threatened to withhold millions in federal funds from the city unless the mural was removed and the plaza renamed.
content: Crews began removing the Black Lives Matter mural in Washington on Monday after a Republican lawmaker threatened to withhold millions in federal funds from the city unless the mural was removed and the plaza renamed.
source.name: The New York Times
